title: 107_hr1311
content: The "Fairness in Securities Transactions Act" amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to reduce transaction fees from "1/300 of one percent" to "1/500 of one percent." The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to revise pooling and allocation of collections, including changes to subsections (b) and (d) regarding off-exchange trades of last-sale-reported securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to revise pooling and allocation of collections, including changes to subsections (b) and (d) regarding off-exchange trades of last-sale-reported securities. The amendments include depositing fees collected under subsections (b) and (c) as offsetting collections to the Commission's account. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to revise pooling and allocation of collections, including changes to subsections (b) and (d) regarding off-exchange trades of last-sale-reported securities. Fees collected for fiscal years 2007 through 2011 shall not exceed the target offsetting collection amount and any excess shall be deposited as general revenue of the Treasury. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to adjust rates for fiscal years 2003 through 2011 to ensure fee collections equal the aggregate sales amount. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to adjust rates for fiscal years 2003 through 2011 to ensure fee collections equal the aggregate sales amount. For fiscal year 2012 and beyond, the Commission will adjust rates to achieve target fee collections. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to adjust rates for fiscal years 2003 through 2011 to ensure fee collections equal the aggregate sales amount. For fiscal year 2012 and beyond, the Commission will adjust rates to achieve target fee collections. Adjusted rates for each fiscal year cannot exceed the rates applicable under subsections (b) and (c). Adjusted rates are not subject to judicial review and take effect at the beginning of the respective fiscal year. If a regular appropriation to the Commission is not enacted at the start of a fiscal year, there will be a lapse of appropriation. The Commission will continue to collect fees at the previous year's rate if a regular appropriation is not enacted. Definitions for target offsetting collection amounts are specified for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2009. The Commission will collect specific fees for fiscal years 2009 to 2011, with target general revenue amounts set for each year. The baseline estimate of sales for any fiscal year is also defined. The Commission will collect fees based on the aggregate dollar amount of securities sales on national securities exchanges and by members of national securities associations, as determined by the Congressional Budget Office. Amendments require projections to be made by March of the preceding fiscal year and reported by April 30. SEC. 4. PAY PARITY PROVISIONS. The Securities and Exchange Commission can appoint and determine the compensation of necessary employees without following certain pay regulations. The Securities and Exchange Commission has the authority to provide additional compensation and benefits to its employees, consulting with relevant agencies for comparability. The Securities and Exchange Commission consults with relevant agencies to ensure comparability in compensation and benefits for its employees. Amendments are made to ensure alignment with other agencies in terms of compensation and benefits. Amendments are made to section 5373(a) of title 5, United States Code, to include section 4(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The fee provisions of sections 2 and 3 of the Act will be effective on October 1, 2001. The pay parity amendments of section 4 will take effect upon enactment, except for section 4(b)(1) which will be determined by the Securities and Exchange Commission within one year of enactment.
